senses.de: To look for something or someone carefully or thoroughly
senses.ex: She is searching for her lost keys.

Tips.title: Action Intensity
Tips.description: Emphasizes the thorough action of looking, more than a glance.
Tips.example: They searched the forest for the missing hiker.

Tips.title: Active Process
Tips.description: Indicates an ongoing effort, not a single quick check.
Tips.example: He searched all day for a new job.

Tips.title: Multiple Places
Tips.description: Can imply looking in more than one location or manner.
Tips.example: We searched high and low for your toy.

senses.ex: The police searched the car for drugs.

Tips.title: Careful Examination
Tips.description: Stresses scrutiny, not just a surface look.
Tips.example: The jeweler searched the gem for flaws.

Tips.title: Purpose Driven
Tips.description: Often has a goal, like finding evidence or specific items.
Tips.example: Agents searched his luggage for contraband.

senses.de: To try to find information on the Internet
senses.ex: I searched for tips on how to train a dog.

Tips.title: Digital Search
Tips.description: Refers to using the internet or database to find information.
Tips.example: I searched the web for the latest news.

Tips.title: Technology Dependent
Tips.description: Specific to devices like computers or phones.
Tips.example: She searched her email for the invitation.

senses.de: An act of searching for someone or something
senses.ex: He found his keys after a long search.

Tips.title: Search Endeavor
Tips.description: Refers to a mission or planned action to find something.
Tips.example: The search for the lost city took years.

Tips.title: May Be Collaborative
Tips.description: Can be an effort by a group, not just an individual.
Tips.example: A search party was organized for the hikers.

senses.de: To examine legally seized goods or property
senses.ex: The officer searched the bag for illegal items.

Tips.title: Legal Context
Tips.description: Searches can be official and require legal authority.
Tips.example: They needed a search warrant to enter the property.

Tips.title: Privacy Consideration
Tips.description: In legal terms, implies potential intrusion into one's privacy.
Tips.example: The search of her house violated her privacy.

Explore.wordDefinition:
Explore means to travel in or through (an unfamiliar country or area) in order to learn about or familiarize oneself with it.

Explore is about discovery and learning through immersion, while search is about finding something specific.

For example, you might explore a new city to learn more about its culture and history, while you would search for a particular book in a library.

Hunt.wordDefinition:
Hunt refers to searching for something with the intent of capturing or killing it, like hunting for deer or hunting for a criminal.

Hunt is applicable when the goal is to capture or kill something, while search is applicable when the goal is to find something.

Investigate.wordDefinition:
Investigate means to look into something carefully to find out the truth.

It describes when someone is trying to gather information or evidence about a subject. For example, a detective might investigate a crime scene to try and find out who committed a crime.

Investigate is when you are trying to figure out what happened or why something happened, while search is when you are trying to find something specific.

Probe.wordDefinition:
The word ‘probe’ typically means to investigate something or look deeper into it. For example, a doctor may use a probe to examine a patient's ear or a detective may use a probe to uncover evidence in a case.

In short, ‘probe’ refers to investigating or examining something, while ‘search’ refers to looking for something. Probe is applicable when you're exploring or investigating something specific, while search is applicable when you're trying to locate something that is missing or hidden.

Quest.wordDefinition:
A quest typically refers to a long and challenging journey in search of a specific goal or objective. It often involves facing obstacles, overcoming challenges, and experiencing personal growth along the way.

Examples of quests could include a hero's journey in a story, a religious pilgrimage, or a personal endeavor such as finding one's purpose in life.

It can be a more practical and straightforward process than a quest, and may not involve any significant personal growth.

A quest is more focused on the journey and the personal growth that comes with it, while a search is more focused on the end goal and finding what one is looking for.

Scan.wordDefinition:
Scan means to quickly look over something to get a general idea of what it is or to find something specific.

For example, you might scan a page of a book to look for a particular word or to see if it's interesting before reading it more carefully.

So, scanning is used when you want to get a general idea of something or find something quickly, and searching is used when you want to find something specific, often through more thorough and intentional efforts.

Scrutinize.wordDefinition:
Scrutinize typically means examining something very closely, carefully, and in detail in order to discover any faults, errors, or inconsistencies.

For example, a teacher might scrutinize a student's essay to make sure it meets certain standards.

Both words involve looking at something closely or thoroughly, but they are used in different contexts. Scrutinize is more focused on looking for faults, while search is more focused on finding something that is missing.

Seek.wordDefinition:
Both search and seek mean to look for something, but search is more commonly used to describe a systematic and methodical process of looking for something, while seek is more often used to describe a purposeful and intentional effort to find something.

For example, you might say you are going to search your room for your missing keys, but you might say you are going to seek out new opportunities in life.

Ultimately, both words can be used interchangeably in many cases, but search is often associated with a more thorough or exhaustive process, while seek is often associated with a more focused or intentional approach.

quotes.Text: I have respect for what other people believe. What I believe in my own life is that it's a search for how I can do things better, whether it's being a better man or a better father or finding ways for myself to improve.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Tom Cruise

quotes.Text: It is by not always thinking of yourself, if you can manage it, that you might somehow be happy. Until you make room in your life for someone as important to you as yourself, you will always be searching and lost.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Richard Bach

quotes.Text: It no longer bothers me that I may be constantly searching for father figures; by this time, I have found several and dearly enjoyed knowing them all.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Alice Walker

quotes.Text: You will never be happy if you continue to search for what happiness consists of. You will never live if you are looking for the meaning of life.
quotes.Title: French Philosopher
quotes.Name: Albert Camus

quotes.Text: I've been searching for ways to heal myself, and I've found that kindness is the best way.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Lady Gaga

quotes.Text: Passion surprises. One doesn't search it. It can happen to you tomorrow.
quotes.Title: French Actress
quotes.Name: Isabelle Adjani

quotes.Text: I search for thrill in my characters because I am a boring person.
quotes.Title: Indian Actor
quotes.Name: Mohit Raina

quotes.Text: My whole life I've been a seeker, searching for something.
quotes.Title: Writer
quotes.Name: Mike White

quotes.Text: Between truth and the search for it, I choose the second.
quotes.Title: American Historian
quotes.Name: Bernard Berenson

quotes.Text: I'm on a search for the truth.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Nancy Grace
